div.head: Cyprus Government Railway.
div.p: The Limassol S.S. Co. steamers with good passenger accommodation run between Cyprus & Egypt as follows:—

Trains run alongside the steamers on the quay, and passengers can be conveyed to Famagusta, Nicosia, Morphou and intermediate stations. Good hotel accommodation for tourists is provided at Famagusta, at the Savoy Hotel (Mr. Najem Houry proprietor). Olympus Hotel, Mount Troodos, 6000 ft. above the sea. Magnificent Scenery. Perfect climate. Season May to end of October. For information apply to Mr. Najem Houry, Managing Director of Cyprus Hotel Co., Army Contractor, Limassol, Cyprus. There is a good carriage road from Kopia (on Railway) to Troodos. At Famagusta may be seen the fine old Latin Cathedral (now a mosque) begun in 1300 and finished in 1312, together with other ancient ruins and the Venetian fortifications, the finest in the world. Also the tower or palace, the scene of "Othello'' and of Ford's "Lover's Melancholy.'' The climate of Cyprus in the winter months is delightful and the Island will well repay a visit.
Information as to tickets, trains, etc., may be obtained of Messrs. Thomas Cook & Son, Egypt, or from the General Manager Railways, Famagusta. G. BERT DAY, General Manager. 29248—31-12-907

div.head: CRIME IN EGYPT.
div.p: A recent issve of the London "Daily News" tains a letter from "an ian Correspon t" on the subject of crime in Egypt. That the gentleman who penned the article in question is in no way troubled as to whether his statement contains a moiety of veracity, is sufficiently evident in the following extracts which are ludicrous in their absolute disregard for truth. "Hardly a day passes bat the local Press chronicle some fearful outrage resulting in the death of the victims, perpetrated by armed brigands, banded together for the - pose of vengeance or plunder. But this is all. It not unfrequenly happens that o whole of the inhabitants of neighbouring villages attack one another, when a species of pitched battle takes place, many dead and wonnded being left on the field." The writer ot the above remarkable passage goes on to explain that "the authorities" who are respon sible tor public security are at their wits end to discover an effective preventative" and in conclusion he advocates the formation of a, commission "to overhaul the administration of justice from top to bottom."

'Our London contemporary is evidently the possessor of a correspondent who is gifted with the power of i imagination to a marvellous degree, or else one who is extraordinarily easily gulled, for any one who knows anything of the state of Egypt in the present day, also knows that though the occurrence of murder cases are all too frequent, there is no approach to the state of affairsso luminously described in the paragraphs which we have quoted above. Lord Cromer's much quoted paragraph en the Particulars of additional intermeaiate increase of crime is of course paraded as an undeniable witness of the horror of the situa. tion, and, we apologise if we are wrong, this paragraph is introduced with words which strike us with a distinctly familiar ring. Is it beyond the bounds of possibility that they have appeared at no very remote date in the columns of a local contemporary!

Whatever the motives which prompted the writer to resort to the extravagancies of which he is guilty, whether he was really actuated by a genuine desire to benefit the country by what he considered to be harmless exaggerations, penned in the hope that they might attract the attention of the home Parliament, or whether, and this weuld seem more probable, he hada certain space to fill, and conscientiously proceed. ed to fill it regardless of truth, the very wildness of his assertion will debar it from receiving serious attention, even by the more advanced sections of the Radical party at home, and itis a pity that the which is responsible for its prodaction Id not have exercised more care in the editing of their correspondent's work. No good turn was ever served by the policy of antruths, and though we do not doubt bat what our contemporary is guiltless of the desire to deceive, it is oéevertheless unfortanate that it should have become the medium of pablication for such a letter as that from which we have quoted.

Asa matter of fact, the sitaation in the provinces is at last shewing sings of improve went, which if slight, is considering the manifold diffieulties which lie in the way of suppression of crime which has once got a foothold in such a country as this- The subject has for a long time been receiving the active consideration of both the Ministers of Justice and of the Interior. As we have previously pointed oat, the change from one aystem to another is necessarily one which is franght with unavoidable dangers, and the old system under which the omdeh reigned ina state of practical supremacy being no longer tenable, it was necessary to introducss change, and it is to this fact that the increase of crime was primarily due, the newer laws which demand the swearing of witnesses before conviction being unfortunately regarded in the ixht of leniency, tainted by weakness, by those who came uuder their jurisdiction.

There is no commission necessary. The Government is alive to the fact that exceptional activity is necessary in the provinces, and all that it is possible to do is being done, with the result that as we have already stated, the more serious offences would already appear to be checked, and we are of the opinion that were a commission formed, the members being of any European country which has had experience of dealing. with countries such as Exypt, that their finding would ee justity the action-of the Government in the matter, without being able to propound one effective suggestion which has vot already been applied.

The inauguration of a system empowering the Government to deport criminals would do much to strengthen their power in dealing with this - | question. Many arguments have been brought to bearagainst this innovation, the chief of which appears to be that the same code does not at present hold good in any European country, the people who bring these arguments forward apparently forgetting that the prevailing situations are entirely at variance in the two continents. Deportation was at one time considered necessary in England, among other European countries, and the laws pertaining to it were undoubtedly exercised with beneticial effect in those early days, but such is the sickly sentimentality ofa portion of the present day generation, that the bare suggestion of the revival of such methods is regarded with horror, though it is not more than about sixty years since the same system was applied at home upon those criminals who had proved the ineftectuality of more lenient measures as applied to themselves.

The doctrine of the humane treatment of our fellows is noble in its every degree, bat the morbid extension 'of sympathy to the criminal classes at the expense of the law-abiding population is poisonous in its effect upon a nation Deported criminals are subjected to treatment every whit as humane as they would receive were they located in the local jail, and why it should be considered necessary to confine them to local imprisonment at the expense of the country, when by deporting them for a period, they would be given every opportunity of training themselves to become useful members of society, isa question that can: never receive a satisfactory reply.

div.head: Port Said Coal Strike.
div.p: Our Port Said correspondent wires that the bunkering Arabs cane out on strike last night.

div.head: Caird Zoo.
div.p: A large aiubis baboon from the Blue Nile has been presented to the Zoological Gardens, Cairo, by Wishaw Bey.

div.head: The Sabakha Canal
div.p: The Sabakha Canal Canal will be closed at its bead near Nezlet Hafiz in Aggiout Province fora period of thirty days beginning on the 15th of January next.

div.head: A Xmas Fete.
div.p: Mr. F. Reinsperger, the popular manager of the New Khedivial Hotel at Alexandria, bas issued invitations for a Xmas Tree on the 24th inst. and the fate should prove a great success.

div.head: Fayoum Cirole of Irrigation.
div.p: The canals in Fayoum Province will not be closed to-day as formerly notified. The closure is postponed till the 26th instant when all canals will be closed.

div.head: L'amie de Ia Jeune Fille.
div.p: The Cairo Branch of "L'Amie de la Jenne Fille" has delegated an agent of the society to be stationed at the Cairo station in order to meet and render assistance to young girls who are travelling alone.

div.head: Crime in the Provinces.
div.p: Our Damanhour correspondent reports that three natives, including one woman, have been arrested of the charge of murdering a certain Abdul Gawad Mouled, whose body was found on the agricultural road véar Riaz Pashe station.

div.head: Balloon Ascent in Cairo.
div.p: Mr Serge Outotchkine will make a balloon ascent from the Esbekieh gardens at 3 o'clock on Saturday afternoon. On his second or third ascent he will be accompanied by Mr. Grosdemange, of our contemporary "Progrés."

div.head: Egyptian Deita Land.
div.p: The Committee of the London Stock Exchange has beén asked to allow the following security to be quoted in the Official List :— Egyptian Delta Land and Investment Co, Limited. Further issue of shares of £1 each, fully paid (bearer warrants'.

div.head: The Brindisi Mail.
div.p: The mail for Europe via Port Said and Brindisi will be made ap at the G.P.O. Alexandria, at 3.10 p.m. on Sunday 22nd for ordinary correspondence, 2.10 p.m. for registered correspondence, at noon for money orders and insured articles and at 6 pm on Saturday 21st for parcels

div.head: Sudanese Slaves
div.p: During the month of November nineteen Sudanese women and nine Sudanese men were granted manumission papers in Cairo city. Nine women and three men, also Sudanese, received them at |Alexandria, and three men and three womenfall of Sudanese nationality were also granted them in Suez.

div.head: A Warning
div.p: The Telephone Company Egypt,;Ltd., requests us to warn the public against-a gang of thieves, who, on pretext of carrying « ladder, pretending to be employed with the company, have recently entered two buildings, from the terraces of which they have stolen all they could find. The police have been advised.

div.head: Exhibition of Survey Maps.
div.p: His Highness the Kbedive will open the exhibition of the maps prepared by the Survey Department, which is to be held in the Geological Museum in the, gardens of the Public Works Ministry, on the 9th January next, after which date the exhibition will be open to the public from 9 a.m. until 4.30 p.m.

div.head: Ship Canal and Egyptian Cotton.
div.p: At the annual meeting of the Manchester Cotton Association, Limited, held at Manchester, Mr. Frederick Reyner, who was in the chair, referring to Egyptian cotton, said it did not need much of a prophet to foretell that within another ten years practically the whole of the Egyptian cotton used if Lancashire mills would come vid the Manchester Ship Canal.

div.head: "Fascinating Egypt."
div.p: Such is the title of a well got up advertising manual and popular guide to Egypt, compiled by Mr. Weiuthal, assisted by Mr Philip Taylor and Mr. Holloway. It is in three languages English, French and German and the illustrations are excellent. "Egypt", the special edition of "The African World", for the present season, is another compilation by Mr Weinthal. Thee is an interesting article on cotton in Egypt by Mr. Adolphus Bogdadly

div.head: Ministry of Finance
div.p: Mr. McKillop has been appointed Chief Inspector to the Ministry of Finance and the following appointments to the andermentioned mudiriehs are also announced: Mr. Dallin, Mr. Blomfield, and Mohamed Effendi Forad to the mudirieh of Gharbieh and Galioubieh; Mr. Barnett Stewart and Mr. Hallis to Behera and Menoufieh ; Mr. Wild and Mr. Hogg to Dakahlieh ; Seleh Effendi Ghirghis to Sharkieb and Ghizeb ; Salem Effendi Moukbtar to Beni Souef and Fayoum ; Abdul Aziz Effendi to Minieb ; Ahmed Effendi Saleh to Assiout and Guirgeh ; Mobamed Effendi Ramzi to Keneh and Assouan ; Mobaured Effendi Mousta and Mobamed Effendi Po for special service.

div.head:
Egyptian Politics
THE NEW PARTY.
div.p: CONSTITUTIONAL REFORM LEAGUE.

As announced a short time ago in these columns the moderate nationalists have been busy organising themselves into a party under the chairmanship:of Sheikh Ali Bey Yussef. Convenient premises have been taken on the first floor of a house nearly opposite the Turf Club, and in about a week's time all will be ready for holding the inaugural meeting of the general committee. Some days ago the Arabic version of the statutes of the league setting forth its aim' and constitution was published, an Englirh haa of which has just reached va. The following is an extract :-—
PRINCIPLES OF THE LEAGUE.
(a) Maintendnce of the Khedivial authority as guaranted by the Firmans conferring upon Egypt Administrative Independence.
(b) Reliance upon the pledges given and declarations made by Great Britain at the time of the Occupation and claiming their fulfilment.
(c) A demand for representative institutions invested with full political and administrative powers in so far as Egyptians and Egyptian interests are alone concerned.
(d) Primary Education to be general and gratuitous.
(e) Arabic to be the medium of instruction in all Egyptian Government Schools.

(f) Posts in the Egyptian Government to be given to natives according to their capacity and merit with the object of diminishing as far as possible the number of foreigners in the service of the Government and thus enabling the Egyptians to learn to govern themselves.

(g) Extension of the Jurisdiction of the Mixed Courts, which already try civil, commercial and petty offences, to criminal cases in which foreigners -are concerned until such period as it may be possible to inaugurate unity of Jurisdiction and thus affirm the great principle of justice for all who inbabit the same country, namely, "Equality before the Law."

The leagve's chief office is in Cairo bat it is contemplated establishing branches in all the principal towns of Egypt. An administrative council consisting of fifteen members selected from a general committee unlimited in numbers, and which has already been extensively joined, will carry out the arrangements of the league. Members of the committee will pay an entrance fee of L.E. 2 and an annual sub- | scription of LE. 5, whilst ordinary members will be admitted on payment of P.T. 20 and an an annual subscription of P.T. 560. One of the rules contains a very salutary provision, namely, that religious topics shall be excluded from discussion save 80 far as the management of religions institations is concerned. The meaning of this is that whilst the league shal! he free to criticise the administration of ecclesiastical endowments such as the Wakfs and Al-Azhar "with a view to introducing feforms of, general utility" it shall not lay itself open to the charge of promoting Pau Islamic propaganda. For the rest, the aims of the league do not present any feature sicenien develty or disconcerting tendencies.
All the claims put forward have been already foreshadowed in the speeches and manifestoes of Sheikh Ali Yaissef and Hafiz Effendi Awad.

Political groupingsin Egypt resolve themselves into three sections, the first of which demands the evacuation of the English from the Nile Valley unconditionally, the second, so soon as the Egyptians shal] become capable of governing themselves and have given proof that by the departure of the English political and commercial interests shall not be injured ; and the third desire to remain for ever under British tutelage. Needless to add that the second section is represented by the league Its demands, however remote some of them may he from realisation, are certainly concluded in language of scrupulous moderation, and are not calculated to wound the susceptibilities of the most staunch Imperialist. It is to the credit of the founder of this movement and his coadjutors that they should have framed a body of rules which are on the whole clear and com prehensive. Their programme, too, has been well reeeived by the Arabic Press and the public whith had beeome confused by a ple thora of political programmes and nausented by the fanfaronade and _ rhetorical falsetto of Mustapha Pasha Kamel. Little to the liking of this frothy phrase-monger must be the evergy displayed by his nationalist competitors in completing sach an organisation which has already been formed by some of the most aceompilshed writers in the Arabic Republic ot Letters. He feels evidently that some counter effort must be made and he theretore proposes to pronounce one of his illuminating dixcourses on the 27th inst. before a meeting of the so called nationalist party, when he will discuss the object of his party about which he has for long years taken good care that the public shall be in no doubt. We may therefore expect nothing but a rechauf/# of his "Anglais et Egyptiens" seasoned with choice morsels from the Zizinia oration, But there is to be something more. No utterance of his would be complete without an out-pouring of the vials of his wrath upon those who dare to differ from bim. So we are to be regaled with an account of the machinations employed by his enemies in attacking him. Who ever said that he recognises only two classes of men—tools and enemies—was probably not far from the mark. And as a final bonne bouche he will demonstrate in an eloquent peroration— Kamel is nothing if not eloquent—of the tub-thumping order, that his party consisting of his brother# his sisters his cousins and his aunts is the only—the very only—one which cen Egypt, where too there is a political awakening, ag well as in India. In Europe, the formation of a political organisation is such sn everyday affair that it attracts but little or no attention. Here, however, being an entirely new experiment, it is regarded in native circles as an event of considerable importance. For ourselves we can Only say that we shall watch its development with interest unmixed with anxiety.

div.head: Personal and Social
div.p: Prince and Princess Windischgraets are staying at the Cataract Hotel, Assouan.

Mr. Winston Churchill has now passed the frontier of the Egyptian Sudan. On the 4th inst. he passed through Wadelai, which is 206 miles from Gondokoro and 112 miles from Nanuli, the headquarters of the Nile Province and the residence of an assistant commissioner.
Sir Eldon and Lady Gorst with Sir William Garstin will leave for Upper Egypt and the Sudan on Thursday next and will meet Mr. Churchill at Assouan.
Sir Eldon will return to Cairo on the 26th proxo.

Lady Alexander Paget is setting out from London for Cairo to join her son, Lord Anglesey, who has jast returned from big game shooting in South Africa. Lady Paget proposes visiting Paris and Naples en route, after which she and her son will go up the Nile together.

Lord Vivian, who,as a special cable we published on Wednesday from London announced, has succeeded in divorcing his wife in the suit in which the co ndent was the well-known Anglo Egyptian financier, Mr. Alfred Curphey, is quite a young man, having not yet attained thirty. He is the fourth holder of a Barony created in 1841 and is also a Baronet, a title created in 1828. The first Baroh was Equerry to the "First Gentleman in Europe" and subsequently became Commander of the Forces in Ireland'and Master General of the Ordnance.

The present Peer is the son of the third Baron, and his mother was the daughter of R. G. Duff, of Ryde, Isle of Wight. He succeeded to the title on the death of his father in 1893. He was educated at Bton and joined the 17th Lancers.

In the Sonth African War he was severely wounded His seat is at Glynn, near Bodmin, and heis the owner of about 8,300 acres. Previous to the birth of his only son, the heir to the title was his cousin, Anthony Vivian, of the Rifle Brigade.
Mrs. Bullock will not be ''At Home" on Sunday afternoon next.

Dr. Bedloe, of Washington D.C., returned from America to Egypt on Monday last by the North German Lloyd Steamer "Hohensollern" and will spend the holidays in Alexandria with his old collegeclass-mate Dr. Love, after which they will make the tour of the Nile and Sudan.

div.head: A FATAL FALL.
div.p: A sad accident occurred yesterday afternoon aboard the Norwegian 8.8. "Hiemw." Mr. A. Principe, who had been sent by the Mixed Tribunals as an expert to examine some dawaged cargo, was standing by an open hold, when he slipped and fell down head first to the bottom ; his head struck against an iron bar and fractured the skull, causing instantaneous death.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS.
div.p: The German training ship "Stein" arrived in Alexandria harbour this morning.
The Ellerman liner "Assiout" arrived at Liverpool last Wednesday.

div.head: BOURSE AND BANKING CO. OF EGYPT LIMITED.
div.p: TO THE EDITOR OF THE "EGYPTIAN GAZETTE." Sir,-The recent decision of the British Consular Court, declaring that the actions of the Directors of Bourse and Banking Co. of Egypt Ltd., in refusing to issue any certificates or share warrants to bearer of the Company, was illegal, will probably lead to still further interesting developments in connection with the investigation of the affairs of this Company, which had so short and so disappointing a
career.

It has been argued that because the contracts rendered to their clients by the brokers contained the clause that all operations were subject to the rules and regulations of the Alexandria Bourse, that the clients must there- fore submit to any conditions, which the committee may in their wisdom see fit to impose; but however powerful a body the As- Bociation de Courtiers en Valeurs may be, they are still amenable to the law, the same as other people, and the decision of the committee in the case of the Bourse and Banking Company of Egypt Ld. to make a new regulation retroactive, would undoubtedly meet with short shrift, should any of the unfortunate share holders, who had sold their shares at a premium, decide upon taking legal action to compel their brokers to accept and pay for the shares at the price at which the sale was ef fected.

Such a course would probably entail unplea sant consequences to many equally unfortunate brokers and would lead to still further complications, as those of them who subscribed, at the time to what may be called the Arditi Brothers Relief Fund, would naturally demand repayment of the amounts contributed by them to carry the Bourse and Banking salvage scheme through; and as the subscrib ers to the fund in question received in exchange for their cash, certain promissory notes of the Arditi Brothers, payable at various dates it would be interesting to find out by means of a legal action, what parties could be made liable to refund the amounts subscribed by the principal brokers interested in the fa mous so-called "settlement" of the dealings in the shares of the Bourse and Banking Company of Egypt Ltd.
I am Sir,
Yours faithlully ESMEH.
Alexandria, 19th December.
Monsieur le Directeur
de l'"Egyptian Gazette".

"La Réforme" d'hier sous la signature d'un désintéressé" publie une lettre relative aux transactions faites en Bourse and Banking J'ai recours à votre estimable journal, qui en cette malheureuse affaire a, avec énergie, soutenu les intérêts des véritables intéressés, pour réfuter les arguments du signataire de la susdite lettre.

L'argument principal consiste en la signature par le client de la note où il est dit que "les contractants ont pleine connaissance etc." Il ne faut pas être grand clere pour répondre qu'on a signé en connaissance de statuts établis et non de règlements postérieurs à la date de la note.

Quant à l'art. 15, sur lequel s'appuie "le dé- sintéressé" il ne peut avoir de valeur juridique en la matière; car on ne peut léser d'une ma nière si arbitraire les intérêts d'une masse au profit de quelques courtiers; d'ailleurs le tribunal aura à statuer sur ce cas et nous ne doutons pas de l'issue des débats. En effet, il eut été aisé, en s'appuyant sur cet article, d'annuler complètement les transactions faites sur tel titre sous prétexte que le règlement de ces transactions serait nuisible à tel ou à tel courtier.
"Le désintéressé" plaint les courtiers "ces pauvres courtiers" I comme il les appelle. En effet, le pelé, le galeux d'où nous vient tout le mal, c'est le client.

Mais, permettez moi, Messieurs, qui est-ce qui l'a poussé tant à la spéculation n'est-ce pas vous, qui par votre insouciance et votre incurie et par l'appât d'un courtage à encaisser l'avez poussé à sa ruine. Et maintenant même, le ménagez-vous ? vous le trainez au tribunal, et vous voulez qu'il vous fasse grâce des quelques sons qu'il a pu gagner en actions "Arditi"; ce serait pousser la magnanimité trop loin, et vous ne l'avez pas habitué à ces élans gé-
néreux.
Agréez, Monsieur le Directeur, mes civilités très empressées. "UN INTÉRESSÉ❞
Alexandrie, le 19 Décembre 1907.

div.head: EGYPTIAN CONSTRUCTIONS LTD.
div.p: TO THE EDITOR OF THE "EGYPTIAN GAZETTE." Sir,-May I make use of your widely circulated newspaper to appeal to all the shareholders of the Egyptian Constructions Limited to turn up at the extraordinary meeting of the Company, which is to be held on Saturday next. If they muster in force they can prevent the resolutions being carried and the Board of Directors getting their own way. It, on the contrary, through the slackness of the share- holders the resolutions are carried, then they bave only themselves to blame. The action of the shareholders at next Saturday's meeting will be watched by many persons, who have no interest in the company, for it will show decisively whether shareholders of Egyptian companies can look after their own interesta and prevent directors from doing just as they please, or whether, as is said to be the case, they are so indifferent that they can be treated just as their Boards of Directors think fit.
Truly yours, A SHAREHOLDER.
December Cairo, 18th.

div.head: CALLS ON SHARES.
div.p: TO THE EDITOR OF THE "EGYPTIAN GAZETTE." Sir, I hear that a company in which I am unfortunately interested intends to make a call. I have in vain tried to find a buyer of these shares and my broker informs me that they are unsaleable. It is needless to say that they are far below par. Under the circumstances am I justified in refusing to throw good money after bad and to refrain from paying the call. Perhaps one of your financial correspon- dents can reply.
Truly yours,
ONE MORE UNFORTUNATE."
Cairo, 19th December.

div.head: NEW EGYPTIAN CO.
div.p: The report of the directors of the Oceana Consolidated Company, Limited, presented at the annual general meeting of shareholders held on the 12th inst., contains the following remarks on the New Egyptian Company:-

A dividend of 10 per cent, has been received this year on our investment, the New Egyptian Company having been able to make profitable sales of some of its extensive holdings, both in agricultural land and town sites. The Nile reclamation works carried out by the Company, under the direction of Mr. Beresford, continue to make good progress. Increasing returns are being shown from the steamers and floating plant in the Sudan. General depression following over-speculation set in during the spring, and has been succeeded by a monetary crisis. This has for the present affected the market quotation of New Egyptian shares, which is considerably below the intrinsic value of that Company's assets.

div.head: THE KHEDIVE
div.p: An occasional correspondent writes from Cairo: "To show the friendly interest that H.H. the Khedive takes in the Army of Occupation, it may interest your readers, to know that he has been pleased to present the prizes for the "Lloyd Lindsay" competition, open to teams of 4 from each corps, squadron, half battalion, the M. I. or M. M. P. all ranks (Officers excepted), which will take place at the forthcoming Rifle Meeting at Abbassieh, between the 3rd and 6th February next".

div.head: KHARTOUM'S STREETS
div.p: We understand, says the "Sudan Times," that the appropriation for street improvement will be considerably cut down. This is much to be regretted, as the streets are in a condition that calls for an increase of the appro- priation for their improvement.

The work projected for the immediate future includes the metalling of the streets connecting Sirdar Avenue with Khedive Avenue. The metalling of both avenues will be completed from end to end, so that when this is done, all the northern section of the town will have its streets in an excellent condition. We have not learned, however, whether the funds in hand or in sight are sufficient for this purpose.
HOCKEY

MR. WALLIS'S TEAM v. SUEZ ET.C. On Thursday afternoon last the above match was played at Suez before a large and enthusiastic crowd The teams were as follows. Suez E.T.C. Goal, Owen, backs, Williams and Young, half-backs, Grace, Hubble and Smyth, forwards, Eden, Isgar, Merchant, Butler and Pitluck.
Port Said, goal, Wallis, backs, Williams and Brooks, half-backs, Broatch, Ingram and Rush, forwards King, Tweedie, Field, Beery and
Howe.

Mr. Wallis won the toss and selected the north end of the field. Suez pressed at the start and after a little spirited work Merchant, their centre forward drew first blood. Suez continued to press and for some time Port Said were obliged to play a defensive game, Suez forwards were playing in grand com- bination and pressed hard. Mr. Wallis saved well time after time, and well deserved the applause he received. Isgar was the next scorer for Suez, his shot was a marvellous one at a very difficult angle. From a corner, play bung round the visitors line for some time, but Port Said managed to clear, and play ranged up and down the field. Through effective passing by Eden, Isgar, Butler and Merchant, Suez were able to add their third goal. In a brief attack by Port Said, the home backs had a little work to do but were only once dangerously pressed, and then the defence proved equal to the occasion.
In the second half Port Said showed better
from but found the defence too strong and the ground too fast. Suez often pressed but could not add to their score and when time was called the score stood Suez E.T.C. 3.-Mr. Wallis' team 0.
S. A.-COLAY FILS & STAHL.
MANUFACTURERS OF
FINEST WATCHES and JEWELRY.
? RUB DE LA PATK
PARIS
81 QUAL D BROUTS
ORNEVA

div.head: WEDDING OF >MR. GUY CHRISTOPHER FOSTER AND MISS MARY LOUISE AIDA BORCHGREVINK.
div.p: Mr. Guy Foster, second son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Percival Foster of Alexandria, was married yesterday afternoon to Miss Aida Borchgrevink, only daughter of the Procureur General of the Mized Tribunals, and Mrs. Borobgrevink, of Cliff House, Bulkeley, Ramleh. The Ven. Archdeaon Ward, assisted by the Rev. Norman Lee, Chaplain to the Forces of the Alexandria Garrison, officiated, at St. Mark's Church, Alexandria. The youthful bride, who looked charming, was given away by her father. She wore a lovely dress of white Liberty satin; the folds of the fichu draped bodice were trimmed with the finest Point de Bruxelle, which lace re-appeared in flower on the round Court train. The bridal veil of the rarest Honiton lace was lent by the bridegroom's mother, having been worn by herself when a bride, and the shower bouquet was made by Mrs. Preston. It was composed of lilies of the valley, white camelias, azaleas and roses, with myrtle and asparagus fern sprays tied with white satin ribbons. Her only ornament, was a beautiful pendant in the form of a heart encrusted with diamonds, the gift of the bridegroom's parents. Five bridesmaids were in attendance, three of whom were children. They were Miss Carola Tuck, Miss Ethné Chataway, Miss Agnes Carver, Miss Pauline Satow, and Miss Marian Percival. The bridesmaids were all in Empire dresses of Eau de Nil Liberty satin with face yokes ornamented by two handsome paste circular brooches at each side. They wore green Morocco shoes and mistletoe and holly wreaths, the white and red berries amongst the dark leaves giving a seasonable note to a ceremony which had come into such near proximity to Christmas-tide.

The bridegroom's presents to the two grown up bridesmaids were pendants set with rubies and diamonds, whilst the three little girls were given pendants set with peridots. Each bridesmaid also received a bouquet to match their wreaths, carrying out the old Christmas tradition of our Northern climes. Mr. Hugh Foster was his brother's best man and had only arrived three days previously from Cambridge to take up his duties at the ceremony. The wedding service was fully choral and opened with the beautiful hymn "Thine for Ever, God of love," by Archbishop Maclagan. The other hymns given were "Lead us Heavenly Father" and at the conclusion of the service Bach's hymn "May the Grace of Christ our Saviour," sung kneeling.

The clergy met the bride at the West end and formed a procession up the aisle. The church which is well adapted to a wedding ceremony was carpeted with Persian rugs from the porch to the altar and the choir was tastefully decorated by Mrs. Ward and some of her friends with white roses, deturas and greenery, whilst the West end was formed into a complete palm grove. The choir did their part excellently well and were seated on the Decani side whilst the parents, and Consuls of Great Britain and Norway were seated opposite. As the bridal procession returned from the vestry the three child bridesmaids assisted by three little girls, clad in white, scattered rose-leaves in front of the nearly married pair. The organist, Mr. Heaton, played as the Voluntary, the Triumphal March by the famous Norwegian composer Grieg and concluded the service with Mendelssohn's Wedding March from the Midsummers Night Dream. After the wedding everyone repaired to Cliff House, Ramleh, where Mrs. Borchgrevink held a reception. The weather although boisterous was fortunately otherwise fair and the invited guests, several hundreds of whom availed themselves of their host and hostess' kind invitation, were enabled to get dryfooted to their destination.

The splendid band of the Royal Inniskilling Fosiliers was in attendance and a most enjoyable afternoon was spent, the spacious tents erected in front of the house giving ample room for the large assembly of friends of all nationalities. At 5.30 the newly wedded couple took leave of their relations and friends. Mrs. Guy Foster was in a very neat tailor made gown of a pretty maize and grey striped material with pleated skirt and a three quarter length cut-a-way coat with dark satin revers bordered with white silk galon. A maize straw hat with plume of white feathers completed a charming and suitable travelling costume.

The happy couple had to pass through arches of muslin scarves held over their heads, as they went down the long flight of steps, by young friends of both sexes. We hear it is a Norwegian custom and added a Scandinavian touch to the proceedings. Amidst a shower of rice they sought safety in a motor which glided away down the steep hill and on to Sidi Gaber to catch the 6. 5. train. The honeymoon will be spent at Assouan.
The list of wedding presents will be published to-morrow.

div.head:
Public Consistory
Conducted by the Pope.

div.p: The Pope personally conducted this morning the ceremony of the Pablic Consistory, attended by thousands of invited persons, especially foreigners, including many English speaking people.

Those extraneous to the ceremony gathered in special places, while the Cardinals, Prelates, and "Court" personages assembled to await the Pontiff in another hall. Meanwhile the Cardinals created on Monday, and Cardinals Rinaldini and Ageirre y Garcia, created in the last Consistory, repaired to the Sistine Chapel, where they took their oath of office before the chiefs of the three orders of Cardinals.
In the procession first came the Swiss Guards followed by the personages of the ecclesiastical and lay courts.
His Holiness, in complete pontifical robes, was walking on foot blessing as he went. Following him came another long train of personages, together with the Sistine Choir.

The Pope mounted the throne amid a respectful silence The new Cardinals were then introduced and while kneeling one by one at the Pontiff's feet he repeated the formula "accipe galeram rubrum." Then, separately, after the papal embrace, went to each of the Cardinals and received a fraternal salute, the choir meanwhile singing. After the ceremony was over Pius X. rose, and gave the apostolic blessing and slowly withdrew, the procession reforming as an escort.
Later, Pius X. held a short supplementary Secret Consistory. ( Reuter)

div.head:
PERSIAN GULF AFFAIR.
NO POLITICAL IMPORTANCE.

div.p: In official circles here the Abou Moussa (Persian Gulf) incident is considered as a purely judicial affair and without any political importance.
An Arab had given a concession for the working of a mine on the Island and the concessionaires had concluded a contract for handing it over to a German house.

The Sheikh who possesses the sovereignty of the Island is under British protectorate. He considered this contract as constituting a monopoly for the German house and was under the impression that he had the right of cancelling it.

The statatements regarding the existence of a store of German arms are avoid of foundation. The German Government has begun friedly negotiaions with the British Government regarding the matter. ( Reuter)

The people assembled in the Midan and be- fore the Parliament House dispersed on the an- nouncement' that negociations were being car- ried on between the Shah and Parliament and would otherwise would be suspended. Things looked bopeful until in the afternoon shots were fired in the Midan, when tents were re pitched and the people reassembled. (Reuter)

An explosion has occurred in a store of ex- plosives. The store and a hotel above collapsed. The hotel was full of emigrants, 17 of whom are dead. 71 wounded persons have been extracted from the ruins: many are missing.
( Reuter)
The report of the Government mining engin- eer for 1906/07 shows the total mineral output as £30,111, 708, of which gold amonnt-, ed to £2+,640,490 and diamonds to £2,203,511. ( Reuter)

div.head:
SUDAN GOLD FIELD.
NO REASON TO BE OTHER THAN SATISFIED WITH THE RESULTS.
div.p: The fourth ordinary general meeting of the shareholders of the Sudan Gold Field, Limited, was held on the 11th December, 1907, at No.6, Queen Street Place, E.C., the Right Hon. Lord Vanx of HarrowJen presiding. The Secretary (Mr. W.F. Garland) having read the notice convening the meeting and the auditors' report.

The Chairman said : Gentlemen, you have no doubt all carefuily stadied the directors' report, as well as the balance-sheet to June 80th last, recently issued. Mr. Robert Taylor will, as usual, describe to you the mining details in regard to our last year's work. Turning to the balance-sheet, at June 30th, being the date to which the accounts are made up, there had been called up upon the 155,000 cash shares 15s per share, leaving a liability of bs per shate The comparatively large amount outstanding on calls, viz, £%,626 188, was due to the fagt that a call became payable on June Ist, and that some of the amounts has not been received at the time the accounts were made up. They" were, however, paid shortly after. The expenditure for the twelve months under the heading of "Mining and general expenditure," amounted to £21675 Is 7d. We deduct £42 lls 3d received as transfer fees, interest, etc., leaving £21,832 10s 4d. This includes £1,617 1s 5d written off for deprecia- tion of buildings, machinery, plant, and rolling stock, which is less than the amount written off for the previous year, when the account was dealt with in a somewhat more drastic manner than will again become necessary. The expenditure on capital account for the twelve months was £6,322 12s 4d. The items are fully set out in detail in the repert. Since June 80th, at which date we had a balance of working capital of £42,531 1s 6d,a further 2s 2d per share has been called up, the last call being payable on November 4th At the present moment our balance of working capital is about £22,000.

We think you will have come to the con- clusion, after reading the directors' report, that we have no reason to be other than satisfied with the considerable progress which has been made at the mine during the past year, and with the favourable features which the under- fature. Indeed, I look upon the history Water supply at Nabardi as one of the most i teresting episodesin the history of the mine. When Mr. Liewelyn first visited Nabardi in 1901 there was practically no water there at all. After some months' work witha view to proving the presence of gold, and having acquired the practical certainty of the mine being likely to turn out productive, the water question be- came one of vital importance, and a boring plant was despatched, and some consi- derable time was spent in searching before a supply was found sufficient to provide for the needs of a camp such as would be necessary to develop the mine. Since that time the sapply of water at Nabardi and in its immediate neighbourhood has steadily increased, and our chief service of supply is now likely to be the Maftah well, which is about 16 miles from the mine. That well was originally commenced with the idea that, being in sandstone forma- tion, the chances of finding water were excep- tionally good, for the sandstone is traceable for some ten miles in length until it reaches a range of bills, and it is some two miles in width, and such a formation might naturally be expected to form a sort of catchment area for the drainage of the hills. The depth of the sandstone has not yet been ascertained. The well is at present 190 ft. deep, and is indicating @ probable increased supply as we 'go | deeper, it may be mentioned that, whilst at 182 ft it gave 600 gallons per 24 hours, on being continued another 8 ft the quantity increased to 7,000 gallons. It is, therefore, not unreasonable to assume that from this source we shall get a satisfactory and continuous supply.

Reviewing the whole position, the directors recently came to the conelusion that, as the mine has now reached a stage of development warranting the erection of a mill, there is no longer any reason why the mill should not be installed at the mine itself Until the ore reserves can be more increased the direetors have thought it advisable to erect a 10-stamp mill only, to be added to as cireum- stances render it necessary and expedient. About the time this decision was come to your directors were informed that an opportunity was presenting itself to acquire a mill ata mine in Egypt which las now discontinued operations. Your directors caused this mill to be inspected, and, it having been found to be in good condition, it has since been purchased, and is now on its way to the property. I may say that owing to the distance of the Muftah well from the mine, and the consequent neces- sity for a long pipe-line to carry the water, the cost of erecting the mill at Nabardi and getting all ready for a start will be much the same as it we had erected it on the Nile, but there will be a considerable saving in running it, as the ore will not now have to be carried 180 miles for treatment. Moreover, there will be not only economy, but also many other advantages in treating the ore on the spot, instead of having to keep op a separate establishment on the Nile for that parpose. Before finally determin. ing what treatment beyond amalgamation will be required to extract the highest possible per- centage of the gold contents of the ore, the directors are awaiting the complete result of some tests being carried out by a London firm ona bulk sample from the deeper develop- ments at the mine. So far as the tests have gone, thére would appear to be every probabi- lity that the extraction will be satisfactory. For milling, it is proposed to utilise the water from the Muftah well, and the necessary pipe- line to convey it to the mill site is in course of shipment. It is not certajp as to how soon the mill may be in operation, but we are quite hoping that we shall be able to make a start in May at the latest. Throughout the past year the native labour supply has been ample, and we are glad to say that the health of the camp has continued good.

You will notice that our superintendent, Mr. Holman, retains a very favourable opinion of our prospects, and considers that we ate working upon a true fissure vein, upon which we should vpen up a valuable mine. Although outside of the Om Nabardi mining lease we are at present doing no work, yet, in view of the possibilities in connection with the conces- sion, we have felt desirous of keeping our hold upon the 22,000 square miles originally granted

game was in store for those who lined the ropes.
At exactly 8.30 p.m. the referee lined his men
out. The stripes won the toss and MoArthor
800 spectators. Play was very fast at the start
and the stripes defence was severely pressed.
Walsh and Tripp narrowly missed scoring.
Midfield play now followed until McArthur
burst away and following a rush on the stripes
citadel the sphere was landed in the net,
McArthur doing the needful. On tesuming,
play took a turn towards Boyd and Company.
The latter were however in splendid form,
especially Skelly, time and again the latter
saved the position when all seemed lost, the
greens now tvok play in hand and succeeded
in getting a corner which proved fruitless.
McArthor spoiled a good chance by lying off
side. Play was very even, both teams doing their
utmost.
Skelly was very conspicuous in the greens
defence while Reynolds for the stripes display-
ed wonderful form. The stripes now took play towards Boyd and Company, the former being cheered for a praiseworthy save; play raged fast and furious from this to the interval, the score then reading.
No. 8 Section R. A. M. C. — 1 Goal.
No. 1 Section R. A. M. C.— = Nid.
Second Half.

div.head: AVIS
div.p: La Municipalité met en adjudication les travaux de prolongement de la rue des Parcs au sud de l'ancien cimetière israélite jusqu'au fort el Nahas.
Le cautionnement est fixé à LE. 15.
Le cahier des charges est déposé an Bureau de la Voirie où il peut-être consulté par les intéressés tous les jours de 9 h. à midi, les jours fériés exceptés.
Les offres devront être adressées sous pli cacheté à Monsieur l'Administrateur de la Municipalité avant le 24 December 1907.
Elles pourront également être déposées en séance de la Délégation la même jour à 5h.p.m.
L'enveloppe devra porter en outre la mention: "Soumission pour les travaux de prolongement de la rue des Parcs."

Le cautionnement ou le reçu d'une banque, d'après les conditions du cahier des charges, devra être remis séparément au Service de la Comptabilité Générale avant l'ouverture des offres et au plus tard le 24 December à midi.
Toute offre qui ne remplit pas les conditions ci-dessus sera écartée.
L'Administrateur.
(signé) W.P. Chataway.
Alexandrie, le 13 December 1907.
